Government responses could include increased service provision of many types (health, education, security, etc.); conflict mitigation; sharing local issues at the provincial or national government levels to increase resources available locally; or other actions that are traditionally the government's responsibility but where civil society has had to fill a gap due to government inaction.

title: Number of government mandated policies enforced by semi-formal or traditional leaders
definition:
Government is defined as the bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce laws. This could include councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, provincial councils, parliaments, etc.

Policies are laws or regulations that have been put in place by government.

Semi-formal or traditional leaders are those recognized community leaders that have power to which people respond, but who may not have been directly elected. These often include religious or tribal leaders.

title: Number of government units implementing investment or development plans that include a mechanism for citizen or CSO input
definition:
Government is defined as the bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce laws. This could include councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, provincial councils, parliaments, etc.

Investment or development plans are part of a community's strategic planning that may be done formally or informally. They include investments to improve services or infrastructure.

Civil society is defined as the "third sector," groups and organizations that operate outside of the private/business sector and outside of the government. In many cases, it is organized into civil society organizations, but it does not need to be organized, registered, or formalized. Many effective civil society groups are just collectives of people interested in a particular issues. Women's organizations are those that have a mission to advance the role of women in society and which have a majority of female staff or members.

title: Number of local government liaisons tasked with hearing community needs
definition:
Local government is defined as the local bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce local laws. This could include local councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, etc. 

Liaisons are those people officially appointed by the government to hear community needs and report back to influence government policy. They may be paid employees or volunteers. For example, civil society points of contact, gender advisors, etc.

title: Number of government units implementing new plans that include a gender analysis and incorporate a gendered perspective (based on set index)
definition:
Government is defined as the bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce laws. This could include councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, provincial councils, parliaments, etc.

Investment or development plans are part of a community's strategic planning that may be done formally or informally. They include investments to improve services or infrastructure.

A gender analysis examines each issue according to the different needs, perspectives, access, and power of women, men, girls, and boys. A gendered perspective adjusts the approach to meet the needs of all people, as found in the analysis.

title: Number of meetings called by local govenrment in response to a request or issue raised by a community member
definition:
Local government is defined as the local bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce local laws. This could include local councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, etc. 

Meetings could be town hall meetings, local council meetings, or other public meeting to discuss an issue. In this case, they should be counted if the issue was initially raised by someone not in the government.

title: Number of consultation/planning meetings for community members with head of local government
definition:
The head of local government could be a village head, a more formalized local government head, or a municipality chairperson or mayor.

They may also not define themselves as any of those categories and could simply identify with being a resident of that geographic area.

definition:
Local government is defined as the local bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce local laws. This could include local councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, etc. 

Mercy Corps training could include a formal workshop session, ongoing mentorship or advice, or the sharing of materials.

"Regular opportunities" is defined as 75% of laws or policies passed had public sessions to get community input before being passed.

title: Number of community members, including men, women, boys, and girls, who report an increase in the amount of information they receive on a regular basis from civil society
definition:
Community members are a cross-section of those living in that area. They may self-define as civil society, the private sector, or even government employees themselves. They may also not define themselves as any of those categories and could simply identify with being a resident of that geographic area.

Information could be written, such as pamphlets or message boards or verbal, through word of mouth or mass media like radio or television.

Civil society is defined as the "third sector," groups and organizations that operate outside of the private/business sector and outside of the government. In many cases, it is organized into civil society organizations, but it does not need to be organized, registered, or formalized. Many effective civil society groups are just collectives of people interested in a particular issues.

definition: Local level planning and policy-setting policies are those that local leaders undertake to do community planning or to pass laws and policies.

title: Percentage of people reporting satisfactory results on an issue brought to local government authorities that was effectively addressed
definition:
Local government is defined as the local bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce local laws. This could include local councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, etc. 

Satisfactory results refer to the person having brought the issue being satisfied with the course of action the government took to address it.

title: Number of people who report feeling effectively informed about local security issues by police and security institutions
definition:
Local security issues could refer to the state of security, recent incidents in the area, precautions community members should take to stay safe, or what local officials are doing to promote security.

Security institutions include police, local army, or other groups formally mandated to maintain security.

definition:

They may also not define themselves as any of those categories and could simply identify with being a resident of that geographic area.

title: Number of dialogues between the formal local government structures and traditional/informal authorities

Dialogues are formal meetings, where traditional authorities and local governments come together to discuss current issues or settle disputes. They could have just one person from each group or many people involved.

title: Number of activities initiated and implemented by women members of a government committee
definition: A government committee could be a legislative committee or a more informal group within the government that comes together to set a policy or procedure or address an issue.

title: Number of annual government score card reports produced.
definition:
Government is defined as the bodies elected or appointed to make and enforce laws. This could include councils, mayors, traditional community leaders, provincial councils, parliaments, etc.

The scorecard should provide a number rating or ranking to the government on any issues the organization deems important for government to be able to meet citizens' needs. This should be provided by Mercy Corps to civil society if needed.

title: Number of communities or government institutions implementing best practice examples promoted by Mercy Corps
definition:
Best practices are documented examples of actions or activities that have had a positive impact on other communities or geographic areas. 

A best practice could be considered to be promoted by Mercy Corps if it was included in an MC publication, on the MC website, or if MC staff have verbally shared knowledge of the example with the communities where they work. Specific attention should be given to gender responsive best practices.

definition:

title: Prevalence of stunted children under five years of age
definition: Stunting is a height-for-age measurement that is a reflection of chronic undernutrition. title: Women's Dietary Diversity Score (WDDS)
definition:
DEFINITION:
This validated indicator aims to measure the micronutrient adequacy of the diet and reports the mean number of food groups consumed in
the previous day by women of reproductive age (15-49 years). To calculate this indicator, nine food groups are used:
1. Grains, roots and tubers; 2. Legumes and nuts; 3. Dairy products (milk, yogurt, cheese); 4. Organ meat; 5. Eggs;
6. Flesh foods and other misc. small animal protein; 7. Vitamin A dark green leafy vegetables;
8. Other Vitamin A rich vegetables and fruits; 9. Other fruits and vegetables
The Mean number of food groups consumed by women of reproductive age indicator is tabulated by averaging the number of food groups
consumed (out of the nine food groups above) across all women of reproductive age in the sample with data on dietary diversity.
To collect data for this indicator, a more disaggregated set of food groups than the nine food groups above should be used in the
questionnaire (See Feed the Future M&E Guidance Series Volume 8: Population-Based Survey Instrument for Feed the Future Zone of
Influence Indicators.) For collection and tabulation of this indicator, foods used in condiment amounts should not be counted as having
been consumed.
source: Feed the Future Indicator Handbook 2013. 3.1.9, page 20 (also FFP indicator)

The numerator for this indicator is the total number of children 0-5 months in the sample exclusively breastfed on the day and night preceding the survey. The denominator is the total number of children 0-5 months in the sample with exclusive breastfeeding data.
source: Feed the Future Indicator Handbook 2014 (also FFP indicator and MCHIP/USAID- sometimes worded slightly different)

title: Prevalence of children 6-23 months receiving a minimum acceptable diet (MAD)
definition: This indicator measures the proportion of children 6-23 months of age who receive a minimum acceptable diet (MAD), apart from breast milk. The “minimum acceptable diet” indicator measures both the minimum feeding frequency and minimum dietary diversity, as appropriate for various age groups. If a child meets the minimum feeding frequency and minimum dietary diversity for their age group and breastfeeding status, then they are considered to receive a minimum acceptable diet. Tabulation of the indicator requires that data on breastfeeding, dietary diversity, number of semi-solid/solid feeds and number of milk feeds be collected for children 6-23 months the day preceding the survey. The indicator is calculated from the following two fractions: 1. Breastfed children 6-23 months of age in the sample who had at least the minimum dietary diversity and the minimum meal frequency during the previous day ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------ Breastfed children 6-23 months of age in the sample with MAD component data and 2. Non-breastfed children 6-23 months of age who received at least 2 milk feedings and had at least the minimum dietary diversity not including milk feeds and the minimum meal frequency during the previous day ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------ Non-breastfed children 6-23 months of age in the sample with MAD component data Minimum dietary diversity for breastfed children 6-23 months is defined as four or more food groups out of the following 7 food groups (refer to the WHO IYCF operational guidance document cited below): 1. Grains, roots and tubers 2. Legumes and nuts 3. Dairy products (milk, yogurt, cheese) 4. Flesh foods (meat, fish, poultry and liver/organ meats) 5. Eggs 6. Vitamin-A rich fruits and vegetables 7. Other fruits and vegetables Minimum meal frequency for breastfed children is defined as two or more feedings of solid, semi-solid, or soft food for children 6-8 months and three or more feedings of solid, semi-solid or soft food for children 9-23 months. For the MAD indicator, minimum dietary diversity for non breastfed children is defined as four or more food groups out of the following six food groups: 1. Grains, roots and tubers 2. Legumes and nuts 3. Flesh foods (meat, fish, poultry and liver/organ meats) 4. Eggs 5. Vitamin-A rich fruits and vegetables 6. Other fruits and vegetables Minimum meal frequency for non breastfed children is defined as four or more feedings of solid, semi-solid, soft food, or milk feeds for children 6-23 months. For non-breastfed children to receive a minimum adequate diet, at least two of these feedings must be milk feeds. For detailed guidance on how to collect and tabulate this indicator, refer to the WHO document: Indicators for assessing infant and young child feeding practices, Part 2, Measurement, available at http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2010/9789241599290_eng.pdf
source: Feed the Future Indicator Handbook and FFP indicators

title: Maternal Mortality Ratio.
definition: The ratio of the number of recorded (or estimated) maternal deaths* during a given time period per 100 000 live births during the same time period (the number of maternal deaths in a population divided by the number of live births – depicting the risk of maternal death relative to the number of live births). *A maternal death refers to a female death from any cause related to or aggravated by pregnancy or its management (excluding accidental or incidental causes) during pregnancy and childbirth or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy
source: i) WHO/UNICEF 2011 Monitoring maternal,  newborn and child health: understanding key progress indicators and; ii) WHO Statistical Information System (WHOSIS) http://www.who.int/whos

title: Neonatal mortality rate.
definition: Number of deaths during the first 28 completed days* of life per 1 000 live births in a given year or period. * Neonatal deaths may be subdivided into early neonatal deaths, occurring during the first seven days of life, and late neonatal deaths, occurring after the seventh day but before the 28 completed days of life. The neonatal period commences at birth and ends 28 completed days after birth. Live birth (see Probability of dying under age 5 years).

title: Prevalence of anemia among women of reproductive age
definition: Anemia is measured by hemoglobin concentration in the blood and, for this indicator, is collected among women of reproductive age (15-49 years). Non pregnant women (NPW) with a hemoglobin concentration less than 12g/dl and Pregnant women (PW) with a hemoglobin concentration less than 11g/dl are classified as anemic. Although different levels of severity of anemia can be measured, this indicator measures the prevalence of all anemia, i.e. mild, moderate and severe anemia combined The numerator for this indicator is the total number of anemic women 15-49 years in the sample. The denominator is the total number of women 15-49 years in the sample with hemoglobin data.
source: Feed the Future Indicator Handbook 2013 3.1.9 page 11

title: Under 5 y Mortality Rate (U5MR).
definition: The probability that a child born in a specific year or time period will die before reaching the age of five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates (expressed as a rate per 1000 live births: number of deaths of children less than five years of age per 1000 live births*) *Live birth refers to the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of the pregnancy, which, after such separation, breathes or shows any other evidence of life - e.g. beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord or definite movement of voluntary muscles - whether or not the umbilical cord has been cut or the placenta is attached. Each product of such a birth is considered live born.
source: WHO/UNICEF 2011 Monitoring maternal,  newborn and child health: understanding key progress indicators and: ii) WHO Statistical Information System (WHOSIS) http://www.who.int/whosis/indicatordefinitions/en/

title: Infant Mortality Rate.
definition: The probability of a child born in a specific year or period dying before reaching the age of one, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of that period. (expressed as a rate per 1000 live births: number of deaths of children less than one year of age per 1000 live births*) *Live birth refers to the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of the pregnancy, which, after such separation, breathes or shows any other evidence of life - e.g. beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord or definite movement of voluntary muscles - whether or not the umbilical cord has been cut or the placenta is attached. Each product of such a birth is considered live born.

title: Percentage of underweight (WAZ < −2) children aged 0-59 months

The numerator for this indicator is the total number of children 0-59 months in the sample with a weight for age Z score < -2. The denominator is the total number of children 0-59 months in the sample with weight for age Z score data.

The numerator for the indicator is the total number of children 0-59 months in the sample with a weight for height Z score < -2. The denominator is the total number of children 0-59 months in the sample with weight for height Z score data.

title: Percentage youth passing national, international, or proprietary knowledge or skills test
definition:
National knowledge or skill test as determined by Ministry of Education or ministry or agency accredited to administer vocational or other skill test. International knowledge or skill test as determined by internationally recognized, accredited or reputable education or skill development agencies. Examples of international tests include Trends in International Mathematics and Science
Study (TIMSS) and PIRLS (Progress in International
Reading Literacy Study) [see http://timssandpirls.bc.edu/] and the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) [see http://www.oecd.org/pisa/aboutpisa/]. Proprietary knowledge or skill test as determined necessary due to the absence of existing national or international tests. For example, EGRA and EGMA exams used in DFID-funded Girls Education Challenge (GEC) programming. Passing scores are determined within the guidelines of the exam being utilized but is typically a threshold or % of correct responses to questions out of a total number of knowledge or skills questions on the test. This indicator determines the effictiveness of formal, non-formal or alternative education programs in teaching students new knowledge and/or skills. This is a measure of quality of education and effectiveness of knowledge and/or skill transfer to a young person. This indicator does not measure the relevance or application of the knowledge or skill learned and therefore other indicators in the Social, Peaceful or Economic Engagement indicator categories should be used to measure relevance and/or applicaiton of the knowledge or skill learned. Note: Age disaggregation into the following age segments is requested. Early Adolescence = 10-14 yrs, Later Adolescence 15-19 yrs, Youth = 20-24 yrs. This disaggregation allows us to aggregate our 15-24 yrs segments for a "youth" segment, capture important early adolescent (10-14 yrs) indcators and aligns with industry best practice of designing program activities for segments no broader than 5 years (example: 15-19 is a 5-year age segment). Formal Education: Education provided in the system of schools, colleges, universities and other formal educational institutions that normally constitutes a continuous ‘ladder’ of full-time education for children and young people, generally beginning at age five to seven and continuing up to 20 or 25 years old. Formal education is also referred to as initial education or regular school and university education (UNESCO, 1997).
Non-Formal Education: Any organized and sustained educational activities that do not correspond exactly to the above definition of formal education. Non-formal education may therefore take place both within and outside educational institutions, and cater to persons of all ages. Depending on country contexts, it may cover educational programs to impart adult literacy, basic education for out-of-school children, life skills, work skills, and general culture. Non-formal education programs do not necessarily follow the “ladder” system, and may have differing duration (UNESCO, 1997). Alternative Education: An alternative to formal education based on public school. These programs respond to a range of youth development needs, including social integration, crime prevention, democracy building, girl's education, workforce development, and health education, among many others. These programs have been characterized by creativity, and by a profusion of partners from other sectors of government and from civil society, including communities, private business, and volunteers. The approaches and methodologies used are unconventional to the extent that they are usually not part of national education strategies (Siri, C., 2004. P. 2-3).

title: Number of male and female youth spending two or more hours a week participating in civic activities
definition:
This indicator counts the number of youth who spend greater than or equal to two hours in a week participating in productive activities organized and implemented individually or collectively. To be considered, these activities need to aim to improve the well being of communities or society in general. These activities could include awareness raising on issues of community concern, minor public space or infrastructure improvements (trash removal, recreational facility improvement, etc.), advocating/influencing change in policy, etc. This indicator does not measure the community perception of the impact of these activities. Note: Age disaggregation into the following age segments is requested. Early Adolescence = 10-14 yrs, Later Adolescence 15-19 yrs, Youth = 20-24 yrs. This disaggregation allows us to aggregate our 15-24 yrs segments for a "youth" segment, capture important early adolescent (10-14 yrs) indcators and aligns with industry best practice of designing program activities for segments no broader than 5 years (example: 15-19 is a 5-year age segment). Civic participation and civic engagement are often used interchangeably, and there are multiple definitions of these terms based on different cultural contexts. For the purposes of this study, civic participation can be defined as individual or collective actions in which young people participate to improve the wellbeing of communities or society in general,
and which provide opportunity for reflection (e.g. an organization where young people are recruited, offered leadership opportunities, participate in activities that improve the community, and are trained and mentored). Generally, work is done for minimal or no compensation.

title: Percentage of youth who believe the use of violence in support of a social or political cause is never justified
definition: This indicator measures propensity towards violence by measuring whether respondents justify violence or not in support of a social or political cause. Formal Education: Education provided in the system of schools, colleges, universities and other formal educational institutions that normally constitutes a continuous ‘ladder’ of full-time education for children and young people, generally beginning at age five to seven and continuing up to 20 or 25 years old. Formal education is also referred to as initial education or regular school and university education (UNESCO, 1997).
Non-Formal Education: Any organized and sustained educational activities that do not correspond exactly to the above definition of formal education. Non-formal education may therefore take place both within and outside educational institutions, and cater to persons of all ages. Depending on country contexts, it may cover educational programs to impart adult literacy, basic education for out-of-school children, life skills, work skills, and general culture. Non-formal education programs do not necessarily follow the “ladder” system, and may have differing duration (UNESCO, 1997). Alternative Education: An alternative to formal education based on public school. These programs respond to a range of youth development needs, including social integration, crime prevention, democracy building, girl's education, workforce development, and health education, among many others. These programs have been characterized by creativity, and by a profusion of partners from other sectors of government and from civil society, including communities, private business, and volunteers. title: Number of male and female youth reporting inter-personal connections that provide helpful resources
definition:
# of youth reporting inter-personal connections, defined as relationships, that are helpful to them in pursuing their education, social/civic, peaceful, or economic engagement goals. Types of relationships and resources can include: 1) Bonding Relationships that facilitate trust and support with peers within the same network. A network is typically a homogenous group of youth that share a similar identity (race, ethnicity, language, nationality, sex, religion, political outlook, neighbourhood, social background/income, educational
attainment). This is often referred to as Bonding Social Capital and is intended to strengthen deep personal relationships that allow for members of the network to share personal information and receive social support from peers. In other words, this network becomes a support system for youth seeking support and guidance. In some programs, Bonding Social Capital may be considered as a necessary precondition for Bridging or Linking social capital. For example, prior to asking a group of Syrian adolescent refugees to work with Jordanian host community peers on community projects (a bridging social capital activity) it may be necessary to build trust and support within the group of Syrian adolescent refugees to address their shared condition of physical and social isolation, hardship and humiliation (a bonding social capital activity). of physical and social isolation, hardship and humiliation (a bonding social capital activity). At the same time, it's important to not build bonding social capital to the exclusion of individuals outside the group. While important for social relationships, it's important that homogenous relationships not become exclusionary to other groups. 2) Bridging Relationships, also known as Bridging Social Capital, are relationships with youth from different networks, neighborhoods, communities, religions, genders, etc. It should be defined from the beginning across which groups the programs intends to build relationships. A different network is typically not homogonous to the network the youth participant self-identifies with and may be represented by a different group based on race, ethnicity, language, nationality, sex, religion, political outlook,
neighbourhood, social background/income, educational
attainment. The nature of these new relationships should be intended to promote positive and productive interaction to enhance cross group relations (i.e. build social cohesion, address shared community concerns) and includes working together on social, civic and economic engagement activities. In some programs, activities designed to build Bridging Social Capital may need to be preceded by Bonding Social Capital activities. Similarly, activities aimed at building Bridging Social Capital may be considered a necessary precondition for Linking Social Capital. For example, a young person displaced from their home province by a natural disaster and relocating to a new province would likely need to establish new relationships with people of a different ethnicity or religion (brdiging social capital) in order to then learn about and access potential employers (linking social capital) to pursue employment opportunities. 3) Linking Relationships, also known as Linking Social Capital, are relationships with people (not necessarily youth) from networks that are external (the young person doesn't currently interact with members of that nework) and provide access to power and new opportunities (education, jobs, civic engagement, etc.). The nature of these new relationships should be intended to provide the young person with new opportunities to obtain the knowledge, skills or other resources that they need to pursue future goals that are productive (do not cause harm to the individual or society). In some programs, Linking Social Capital would be preceded by program activities aiming to build Bonding and Linking Social Capital. title: Percentage of households living below the $1.50/Day/2005 PPP Poverty Line (as measured by the Progress out of Poverty Index)
definition:
The Progress out of Poverty Index® (PPI®) is a poverty measurement tool for organizations and businesses with a mission to serve the poor. The PPI is statistically-sound, yet simple to use: the answers to 10 questions about a household’s characteristics and asset ownership are scored to compute the likelihood that the household is living below the poverty line – or above by only a narrow margin. 
A business or organization must use the PPI scorecard that has been developed for the country in which they operate; 45 PPIs have been developed for 45 countries. There are two steps to using the PPI to determine a person’s level of poverty:
1) The survey and score: The PPI survey contains 10 verifiable questions that a field agent can ask their clients in 5 to 10 minutes. The questions are simple – “What material is your roof made out of? How many of your children are in school?” The survey respondent chooses an answer from multiple choices. It is important that the PPI administrator ask and interpret the survey questions consistently across all clients and as directed by Grameen Foundation in order to maintain accuracy. For many PPIs, there is a corresponding document that provides guidance on how to interpret a question in complicated situations. Each answer is given a value, and the total value of all the answers is the survey respondent’s PPI score.
2) Poverty likelihood look-up table: The PPI administrator uses the PPI look-up table to convert the PPI score to a likelihood that the respondent’s household is living below a poverty line. The look-up table allows the PPI administrator to determine the household’s likelihood of living below multiple national and international poverty lines.
For more information, please visit: http://www.progressoutofpoverty.org/

title: Number of target enterprises who received a financial benefit as a result of the programme’s activities, each year and cumulatively
definition:
The programme must define its “target enterprises,” which are usually the enterprises that a programme is trying to benefit as a result of it activities. An enterprise can be counted no matter how small the financial or other physical benefit it receives but the programme has to show convincingly that only enterprises that actually received a benefit are included. For example, a business enabling programme might work to modify a particular reform allowing car manufacturers to pay less tax by imposing a condition that they must do CSR activities to a specified level. Now all car manufacturers could be potential beneficiaries. However the contribution to scale will be calculated only including those manufacturers who meet the CSR funding condition. 

It is also important to note that enterprises may “drop out” at various levels of the results chain so that the number who actually benefit might be much smaller than the number who might potentially do so. For example, if a mobile operator offers a tele-banking service through 100 agents to 20,000 clients (each agent has 200 clients), then the actual scale of benefit might drop off as follows:
- 80% of agents actually promote the tele-banking service to their clients (so 80 agents offering to 16,000 clients)
- Of those clients, only 70% sign up for the service = 11,200 clients
- Of those clients, only 50% actively (once every 2 months) use the tele-banking service= 5,600 clients
- Of those clients, only 90% get the intended benefit, saving informal money transfer costs by using tele-banking = 5,040 clients

Organization-level technologies and management practices include those in areas such as management (financial, planning, human resources), member services, procurement, technical innovations (processing, storage), quality control, marketing, etc. as a result of USG assistance in the current reporting year. 
Only count the entity once per reporting year, even if multiple technologies or management practices are applied. Any groups applying a technology that was first applied in the previous reporting year and continues to be applied in the current reporting year should be included under “Continuing.” However, if the organization added a new technology or management practice during the reporting year to the ones they continued to apply from previous year(s), they would be counted as “New.” No organization should be counted under both New and Continuing.
Application of a new technology or management practice by the enterprise, association, cooperative or CBO is counted as one and not as applied by the number in their employees and/or membership. For example, when a farmer association incorporates new corn storage innovations as a part of member services, the application is counted as one association and not multiplied by the number of farmer-members.

title: Average HH Score on the Coping Strategies Index (CSI)
definition:
The Coping Strategies Index (CSI) is an indicator of household food security that is relatively simple and quick to use, straightforward to understand, and correlates well with more complex measures of food security. A series of questions about how households manage to cope with a shortfall in food for consumption results in a simple numeric score. In its simplest form, monitoring changes in the CSI score indicates whether household food security status is declining or improving. 

The CSI is based on the many possible answers to one single question: “What do you do when you don’t have adequate food, and don’t have the money to buy food?” 

The CSI requires some “up-front” work to ensure that all the potential answers to this question are known, and that it is adequately adapted to the local situation. But beyond this initial investment, it is quick to administer and easy to analyze and interpret. If collected with data on household food aid receipts and utilization patterns, the CSI provides managers with a tool to improve the management of an emergency food aid program in “real time.” 

For full guidance on how to use the CSI, please refer to:  http://documents.wfp.org/stellent/groups/public/documents/manual_guide_proced/wfp211058.pdf

title: Percentage of program participants (apprentices, interns, trainees and training graduates, etc.) make transitons to full-time/part-time/seasonal and short-term employment
definition:
To assess if individuals are securing short-term, long-term, or seasonal work as a result of their training . Particularly for youth, we would want to ensure that work is safe, equitable, and productive. 

Employment/a job entails labor agreements that generate income in the form of a wage or salary in exchange for a service provided. Employment can include self-employment and farming. Employment can be informal or formal. What is not employment? Cash-for-work or similar short-term emergency/humanitarian interventions, the provision of tools and start-up inputs to an entrepreneur, etc 

Productive work: The inability to find decent jobs can drive individuals towards work that is dangerous, illicit and illegal, such as involvement in the narcotics trade, sex trade, or in a paid militant movement. Although the types of jobs vary in any economy, Mercy Corps promotes legal, decent work which does not threaten positive growth of an individual, community, or society. 
Equitable work: In many countries, a vast inequity exists between salary and benefits for people with different characteristics and demographic profiles. This is especially true for women where they perform the same duties and tasks as a man with an equal title but are paid less. Mercy Corps believes in equitable work, where salary and wages are based on responsibilities and tasks, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, etc. 
Steady work: Entering the labor market, or finding that first job, is often the most difficult part of productive participation in an economy. While multiple income streams and short-term and seasonal work are often necessary (particularly in informal and/or agriculture-based economies), we believe that enabling individuals to find long-term, steady work is critical to ensuring that they play a continual, active role in the labor market.

title: Percentage male and female youth who agree they are valued for contributing to secure and productive societies

title: Prevalence of underweight women

The numerator for this indicator is the number of non-pregnant women 15-49 years in the sample with a BMI < 18.5. The denominator for this indicator is the number of non-pregnant women 15-49 years in the sample with BMI data.

title: Percentage of program participants (apprentices, interns, trainees and training graduates, etc.) make transitions to full-time/part-time/seasonal and short-term employment
definition:
To assess if individuals are securing short-term, long-term, or seasonal work as a result of their training . Particularly for youth, we would want to ensure that work is safe, equitable, and productive. 

Employment/a job entails labor agreements that generate income in the form of a wage or salary in exchange for a service provided. Employment can include self-employment and farming. Employment can be informal or formal. What is not employment? Cash-for-work or similar short-term emergency/humanitarian interventions, the provision of tools and start-up inputs to an entrepreneur, etc 

Productive work: The inability to find decent jobs can drive individuals towards work that is dangerous, illicit and illegal, such as involvement in the narcotics trade, sex trade, or in a paid militant movement. Although the types of jobs vary in any economy, Mercy Corps promotes legal, decent work which does not threaten positive growth of an individual, community, or society. 
Equitable work: In many countries, a vast inequity exists between salary and benefits for people with different characteristics and demographic profiles. This is especially true for women where they perform the same duties and tasks as a man with an equal title but are paid less. Mercy Corps believes in equitable work, where salary and wages are based on responsibilities and tasks, regardless of gender, age, ethnic background, etc. 
Steady work: Entering the labor market, or finding that first job, is often the most difficult part of productive participation in an economy. While multiple income streams and short-term and seasonal work are often necessary (particularly in informal and/or agriculture-based economies), we believe that enabling individuals to find long-term, steady work is critical to ensuring that they play a continual, active role in the labor market.
